title: South Carolina falls to Missouri
text:
Activate your digital access. South Carolina falls to Missouri South Carolina head football coach Steve Spurrier addresses questions about the referees, run game and Lorenzo Nuñez after the Mizzou loss. MYKAL McELDOWNEY/Staff Willie T. Smith III , wtsmith@greenvillenews.com 10:25 p.m. EDT October 3, 2015 Oct 3, 2015; Columbia, MO, USA; South Carolina Gamecocks linebacker Skai Moore (10) tackles Missouri Tigers running back Russell Hansbrough (32) during the second half at Faurot Field. The Tigers won 24-10. Mandatory Credit: Jasen Vinlove-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Jasen Vinlove-USA TODAY Sports) 9 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
COLUMBIA, Missouri – There was little to be said following South Carolina’s 24-10 loss to Missouri at Memorial Stadium. 
The Gamecocks had hoped to find a way to turn their season around against a Missouri team that had not played up to the level it has the previous two seasons when it represented the Eastern Division in the Southeastern Conference championship game. 
If that wasn’t enough, Missouri coach Gary Pinkel was forced to start a true freshman quarterback after suspending three-year starter Maty Mauk for violation of team rules. 
But, as was the case when USC faced Georgia quarterback Grayson Lambert who appeared close to losing his job before completing 24 of 25 passes for 330 yards against the Gamecocks, Drew Lock had the Missouri portion of the 66,751 fans singing "Oh Happy Day." 
He proved to not only be ready for the experience, but thrived, completing 21 of 28 passes for 136 yards and two touchdowns without throwing an interception. 
In addition, the Missouri running game that has been putrid so far this season, picked up 163 yards and scored its first non-Maty Mauk running score. 
That left USC co-defensive coordinator Jon Hoke disappointed with the play of his unit. 
“We were awful (with the run fits),” said Hoke. “Guys weren’t getting to their gaps as cleanly as they needed to. We weren’t as clean on the run fits in the second quarter. 
"At the end of the game it was also disappointing. In eight-man fronts we weren’t as clean in our run fits either.” Oct 3, 2015; Columbia, MO, USA; South Carolina Gamecocks quarterback Lorenzo Nunez (19) runs with the ball as Missouri Tigers defensive lineman Josh Augusta (97) chases during the second half at Faurot Field. The Tigers won 24-10.
